hints.content: Start by understanding the definition of a 'good caption'. A good caption requires that every character appears in groups of at least 3 consecutive occurrences. For example, 'aaa' is good, but 'aa' is not.

Consider how you can change characters in the string. You can change a character to its previous or next character in the alphabet, except for 'a' and 'z'. Think about how this affects the groups of characters.
Identify the groups of consecutive characters in the input string. For example, in 'aaabbb', you have two groups: 'aaa' and 'bbb'. This will help you determine where changes are needed.
Count the length of each group of characters. If a group has fewer than 3 characters, you'll need to perform operations to increase its size. How will you do that?
When a group has only 1 character, it can be transformed into a group of 3 by changing it to the same character twice. For example, 'a' can become 'aaa'.
If a group has 2 characters, you can change one of them to match the other, thus forming a group of 3. For instance, 'aa' can become 'aaa' by changing the next character.
Think about the order of operations. If you have multiple groups to modify, how will you decide which characters to change first to minimize the number of operations?
Consider edge cases where the string might be too short to form any good caption. For example, 'bc' cannot be transformed into a good caption because there aren't enough characters.
When transforming characters, always aim for the lexicographically smallest result. This means you should prefer changing characters to 'a' over 'b', 'b' over 'c', and so on.
As you make changes, keep track of the total number of operations. You want to ensure that you are performing the minimum number of operations necessary to achieve a good caption.
After processing all groups, check if you have successfully formed a good caption. If any group still has fewer than 3 characters, it means it's impossible to create a good caption.
If you find that a good caption is possible, construct the final string in a way that maintains the lexicographical order. Consider how you can append or modify characters accordingly.
Remember to handle the case where the input string is already a good caption. In this case, you should return the string as is without any modifications.
Think about how you can implement your solution efficiently. Given the constraints (up to 50,000 characters), consider the time complexity of your approach.

Before finalizing your solution, review the edge cases and ensure your implementation handles them correctly. This includes strings with all identical characters or strings that are already good captions.

questionNotes: Characters in 'caption' are only lowercase English letters.
Return the lexicographically smallest good caption if multiple exist.
Return an empty string if it's impossible to create a good caption.
